issue.title: [#624] Jmeter client for Command and Control to enable load tests
issue.body: This PR contains HonoCommanderSampler, using which settings required to perform load test for feature Command and Control can be configured. Users can choose the type of protocol being used (http or mqtt) for communication between devices and hono. This sampler establishes connection to hono, get devices that are ready to receive commands under a particular tenant, send commands and receive command responses.This sampler can be combined with standard Jmeter samplers (for example HTTP Request Sampler) to create a test plan for C&C.

body:
> * the application should be able to signal that there is no response expected (in this case no receiver link for a response would be opened at all)

The application should then simply not set the *reply-to* property in the command message.

> * the device should be able to signal for downstream messages in addition to the ttd parameter that there will be no response sent to a potentially received command (called e.g. nor for no response

I do not think that I understand the purpose of this.

> * the adapter should be able to detect a default value for the device regarding the nor parameter

What is this supposed to be good for?

We already have added the concept of a *one-way* command to the [C&C API](https://www.eclipse.org/hono/api/command-and-control-api/#send-a-one-way-command).

However, the protocol adapters need to be adapted accordingly, e.g. the HTTP adapter needs to be changed to not include the *hono-cmd-id* header in the HTTP response if no *reply-to* property is set in the command.
@sysexcontrol are you currently working on this issue?  It is assigned to you but it is not in progress (yet) ...

rename.from: Support command pattern for "fire and forget"

body:
> > * the application should be able to signal that there is no response expected (in this case no receiver link for a response would be opened at all)
> 
> The application should then simply not set the _reply-to_ property in the command message.

That is a reasonable implementation detail. However, the current API needs to be somehow extended as well, since for the client the _reply-to_ property is completely transparent currently (and thus would always be set).
I will extend this part in the description.

> > * the device should be able to signal for downstream messages in addition to the ttd parameter that there will be no response sent to a potentially received command (called e.g. nor for no response
> 
> I do not think that I understand the purpose of this.

This was meant as the possibility for a device to signal that it will (or cannot) reply to any command. At the same time as the `ttd` parameter is given.

The first option demands that the application itself needs to know if a command can be responded by the device or not. This 2nd option would enable an application to send a command, and the underlying API can decide itself if there should be a response from the device or not - the application would be free from this decision.

Thinking about it now, it does not seem to be so obvious to me anymore that this is a necessary feature to have - maybe it is ok to always let the application decide that a command shall be "one-way" or not.
I will remove this point from the issue - it could be implemented later on anyway, if it should be important.

> 
> > * the adapter should be able to detect a default value for the device regarding the nor parameter
> 
> What is this supposed to be good for?

Is (or better: was) meant as an automatic way of setting that a device will not send a reponse to a command. IMHO this should be implemented iff option 2 is implemented (to free the device from having to set it explicitly), but will remove this together with option 2 now from the issue.

issue.title: [#669] Provide one-way pattern for commands.
issue.body:
This is step 1 of a sequence of PRs for implementing #669 : it provides the base for sending one-way commands by using the slightly extended AbstractRequestResponseClient.
The commandClient can decide for each command if a response from the device is expected or not by choosing different send methods:
`sendCommand` or `sendOneWayCommand`.

It was tested with the HTTP adapter and an extended example app - both are not part of this PR though and follow in a subsequent PR.

issue.title: [#669] Alternative implementation for one-way pattern for commands.
issue.body:
This is step 1 of a sequence of PRs for implementing #669 : it provides the base for sending one-way commands in a different implementation (not using `createAndSend` methods anymore, but still sharing the `sendRequest` method with the AbstractRequestResponseClient).
The commandClient can decide for each command if a response from the device is expected or not by choosing different send methods:
`sendCommand` or `sendOneWayCommand`.

It was tested with the HTTP adapter and an extended example app - both are not part of this PR though and follow in a subsequent PR.
